[MS. Trin. Coll. Camb., R. 3. 20, pp. 55â65.] Lo here filoweÃ¾e Ã¾e deuyse of a desguysing to fore Ã¾e gret estates of Ã¾is lande, Ã¾ane being at London, made by Lidegate Daun Iohan, Ã¾e Munk of Bury. of Dame Fortune, Dame Prudence, Dame Rightwysnesse and Dame Fortitudo. beholdeÃ¾e, for it is moral, plesaunt and notable. Loo, first komeÃ¾e in Dame Fortune. Loo here Ã¾is lady Ã¾at yee may see, Lady of mutabilytee, Which Ã¾at called is Fortune, For seelde in oon she dooÃ¾e contune. For as shee haÃ¾e a double face, Right so euery houre and space She chaungeÃ¾e hir condycyouns, Ay ful of transmutacyouns. Lyche as Ã¾e Romans of Ã¾e Roose DescryveÃ¾e hir, with-outen glose, And telleÃ¾e pleyne, howe Ã¾at she HaÃ¾e hir dwelling in Ã¾e see, Ioyning to a bareyne roche. And on Ã¾at oon syde dooÃ¾e aproche A lytel mountaygne lyke an yle; Vpon which lande some whyle Ãer growen fresshe floures nuwe, Wonder lusty of Ã¾eyre huwe, Dyuers trees, with fruyte elade. And briddes, with Ã¾eyre notes glaade, Ãat singen and maken melodye; In Ã¾eyre hevenly hermonye Somme sing on hye, and some lowe. And Zepherus Ã¾eer dooÃ¾e eeke blowe With his smooÃ¾e, attempree ayre. He makeÃ¾e Ã¾e weder clere and fayre And Ã¾e sesoun ful of grace. But sodeynly, in lytel space, Vpon Ã¾is place mooste ryal Ãer comeÃ¾e a wawe and for-dooÃ¾e al. First Ã¾e fresshe floures glade On Ã¾eyre stalkes he doÃ¾e faade. To Ã¾eyre beautee he dooÃ¾e wrong; And Ã¾anne farweel Ã¾e briddes song. Braunche and boughe of euery tree She robbeÃ¾e hem of hir beautee, Leef and blossomes downe Ã¾ey falle. And in Ã¾at place she haÃ¾e an halle, Departed and wonder desguysee. Frome Ã¾at oon syde, yee may see, Ceryously wrought, for Ã¾e noones, Of golde, of syluer, and of stoones, Whos richesse may not be tolde. But Ã¾at oÃ¾er syde of Ã¾at hoolde Is ebylt in ougly wyse, And ruynous, for to devyse; Daubed of clay is Ã¾at doungeoun, Ay in poynt to falle adoun. Ãat oon fayre by apparence, And Ã¾at ooÃ¾er in existence Shaken with wyndes, rayne and hayle. And sodeynly Ã¾er dooÃ¾e assayle A raage floode Ã¾at mancyoun, And ouerfloweÃ¾e it vp and doun. Her is no reskous, ner obstacle Of Ã¾is ladyes habytacle. And as hir hous is ay vnstable, Right so hir self is deceyuable: In oo poynt she is neuer elyche; Ãis day she makeÃ¾e a man al ryche And thorughe hir mutabilytee CasteÃ¾e him to morowe in pouertee. Ãe proddest she can gyve a fal: She made Alexaundre wynnen al, Ãat noman him with stonde dare, And caste him dovne, er he was ware. So did sheo Sesar Iulius: Sesar a bakars seon. She made him first victorius, Ãaughe to do weel sheo beo ful looÃ¾e; Of a bakers sonne, in sooÃ¾e, She made him a mighty emperrour, And hool of Roome was gouuernour, Maugrey Ã¾e Senaat and al Ã¾eyre might; But whanne Ã¾e sonne shoone mooste bright Of his tryumphe, fer and neer, And he was corouned with laurier, Vnwarly thorughe hir mortal lawe With bodekyns he was eslawe At Ã¾e Capitoyle in Consistorye, Loo, affter al his gret victorye. See, howe Ã¾is lady can appalle Ãe noblesse of Ã¾eos prynces alle. She haÃ¾e two tonnys in hir celler; Ãat oon is ful of pyment cler, Confeit with sugre and spyces swoote And manny delytable roote. But Ã¾is is yit Ã¾e worst of alle: Ãat oÃ¾er tonne is ful of galle; Whoo taasteÃ¾e oon, Ã¾er is noon ooÃ¾er, He moste taaste eeke of Ã¾at toÃ¾er. Whos sodeyne chaunges beon not sofft, For nowe sheo can reyse oon alofft, Frome lowghe estate til hye degree. In olde storyes yee may see Estates chaunge, whoo takeÃ¾e keepe. For oon Gyges, Ã¾at kepte sheepe, Sheo made, by vertu of a ring, For to be made a worÃ¾y kyng; And by fals mourdre, I dare expresse, He came to al his worthynesseâ Moost odyous of alle thinges. And Cresus, ricchest eeke of kynges, Was so surquydous in his pryde, Ãat he wende, vpon noo syde Noon eorÃ¾ely thing might him pertourbe, Nor his ryal estate distourbe. Til on a night a dreme he mette, Howe Iuvo in Ã¾e ayre him sette Ecclesiasticus xxvjo capo. And Iubiter, he vnderstondes, Gaf him water vn-to his handes, And Phebus heelde him Ã¾e towayle. But of Ã¾is dreme Ã¾e devynayle His doughter gane to specefye, And fer to-forne to prophesye, Whiche called [was] Leryopee. Sheo sayde, he shoulde an hanged bee; Ãis was hir exposicyoun. Loo, howe his pruyde was brought adovne. And alle Ã¾eos chaunges, yif Ã¾ey beo sought, Ãis fals lady haÃ¾e hem wrought, Avaled with Ã¾eyre sodeyne showres Ãe worÃ¾ynesse of conquerroures. Reede of poetes Ã¾e comedyes; And in dyuers tragedyes Yee shal by lamentacyouns Fynden Ã¾eyre destruccyounsâ A thousande moo Ã¾an I can telleâ, In-to mescheef howe Ã¾ey felle Dovne frome hir wheel, on see and lande. Ãer-fore, hir malys to withstande, Hir pompe, hir surquydye, hir pryde, Yif she wol a whyle abyde, Foure ladyes shall come heer anoon, Which shal hir power ouergoone, And Ã¾e malys eeke oppresse Of Ã¾is blynde, fals goddesse, Yif sheo beo hardy in Ã¾is place Oonys for to shewe hir double face. Nowe komeÃ¾e here Ã¾e first lady of Ã¾e foure, Dame Prudence. Loo, heer Ã¾is lady in youre presence Of poetis called is Dame Prudence, Ãe which with hir mirrour bright, By Ã¾e pourveyaunce of hir forsight And hir myrrour, called provydence, Is strong to make resistence In hir forsight, as it is right, Ageyns Fortune and al hir might. For Senec seyÃ¾e, who Ã¾at can see, Ãat Prudence haÃ¾e eyeghen three, Specyally in hir lookynges To considre three maner thinges, Alweyes by goode avysement: Thinges passed and eeke present, And thinges affter Ã¾at shal falle. And she mot looke first of alle, And doon hir inwarde besy peyne, Thinges present for to ordeyne Avysely on euery syde, And future thinges for to provyde, Ãe thinges passed in substaunce For to haue in remembraunce. And who Ã¾us dooÃ¾e, I say Ã¾at hee Verrayly haÃ¾e yeghen three Comitted vn-to his diffence, Ãe truwe myrrour of prouydence. Ãane Ã¾is lady is his guyde, i. providencia. Him to defende on euery syde Ageyns Fortune goode and peruerse And al hir power for to reuerse. For fraunchysed and [at] liberte, Frome hir power to goo free, Stonde alle folkes, in sentence Wheeche beon gouuerned by Prudence. Nowe sheweÃ¾e hir heer Ã¾e secounde lady, Dame Rigwysnesse. SeoÃ¾e here Ã¾is lady, Rightwysnesse. Of alle vertues she is pryncesse, For by Ã¾e scales of hir balaunces Sheo sette hem alle in gouuernaunces. She putteÃ¾e asyde, it is no dreede, Frenship, fauour and al kyns meede. Love and drede she setteÃ¾e at nought, For rightful doome may not beo bought. And Rightwysnesse, who can espye, HaÃ¾e neyÃ¾er hande ner yeghe. She loste hir hande ful yore agoone, For she resceyueÃ¾e gyfftes noone, NoÃ¾er of freonde, neyÃ¾er of foo. And she haÃ¾e lost hir sight al-soo, For of right sheo dooÃ¾e provyde, Nought for to looke on neyÃ¾er syde, To hyeghe estate, ner lowe degree, But dooÃ¾e to boÃ¾en al equytee, And makeÃ¾e noon excepcyoun To neyÃ¾er part, but of raysoun. And for Ã¾e pourpos of Ã¾is mater Of a iuge yee shal heere, Which neuer his lyff of entent Ãer passed no iugement By his lippes of falsnesse; Of whome Ã¾e story dooÃ¾e expresse, Affter his deeÃ¾e, by acountes cleer, More Ã¾ane three hundreÃ¾e yeer, His body, as is made mencyoun, Was tourned vn-to corrupcyoun, Ãe story telleÃ¾e, it is no dreed; But lyche a roos, swoote and reed, MouÃ¾e and lippes werne yfounde, Nought corrupte, but hoole and sounde. For trouth is, Ã¾at he did expresse In alle hees doomes of rithwysnesse. For Ã¾is lady with Ã¾eos balaunce Was with him of acqweyntaunce, Which him made in his ententys To gyf alle rightwyse iugementis. Where fore Ã¾is lady, which yee heer see With hir balaunces of equytee, HaÃ¾e Ã¾e scaalis honged soo, Ãat she haÃ¾e no thing to doo Neuer with Fortunes doublenesse. For euer in oon stant Rightwysnesse, Nowher moeving too ne froo In no thing Ã¾at she haÃ¾e to doo. Loo, heer komeÃ¾e in nowe Ã¾e thridde lady, called Fortitudo. TakeÃ¾e heede, Ã¾is fayre lady, loo, Ycalled is Fortitudo, Whame philosophres by Ã¾eyre sentence Ar wonte to cleepe Magnyfysence. And Fortitudo soÃ¾ely sheo hight, Ageyns alle vyces for to fight, Confermed as by surtee Ageynst all aduersytee. In signe wher of sheo bereÃ¾e a swerde, Ãat sheo of no thing is aferd. For comune profit also she, Of verray magnanymyte, Thinges gret dooÃ¾e vnderfonge, Taking enpryses, wheeche beon stronge. And moost sheo dooÃ¾e hir power preove A communaltee for to releeve, Namely vpon a grounde of trouthe; Ãanne in hir Ã¾er is no slouthe For to maynteyne Ã¾e goode comune. And alle Ã¾assautes of fortune, Of verray stidfastnesse of thought Alle hir chaunges she sette at nought. For Ã¾is vertu magnyfycence Thorough hir mighty excellence She armed Ã¾eos philosophres oolde, Of worldely thing Ã¾at Ã¾ey nought tolde Recorde vpon Dyogenes, On Plato and on Socrates. She made Cypion of Cartage To vnderfongen in his aage For comune proufyte thinges gret; i. republica. And for no dreed list not leet, Ageynst Roome, Ã¾at mighty tovne, For to defende his regyoun. Sheo made Hector for his cytee To spare for noon aduersytee, But, as a mighty chaumpyoun, In Ã¾e defence of Troyes toun To dye with-outen feer or dreed. And Ã¾us Ã¾is lady, who takeÃ¾e heed, MakiÃ¾e hir chaumpyoun[e]s strong, Parayllous thinges to vnderfong, Til Ã¾at Ã¾ey Ã¾eyre pourpos fyne. Recorde of Ã¾e worthy nyen, Of oÃ¾er eeke Ã¾at weere but late, I meene prynces of latter date. Herry Ã¾e Fyfft, I dare sey soo, He might beo tolde for oon of Ã¾oo; Empryses wheeche Ã¾at were bygonne He lefft not til Ã¾ey weere wonne. And I suppose, and yowe list see, Ãat Ã¾ees ladyes alle three Wer of his counseyle doutelesse, Force, Prudence and Rightwysnesse. Of Ã¾eos three he tooke his roote, To putte Fortune vnder foote. And sith Ã¾is lady, in vertu strong, SousteneÃ¾e trouthe, and dooÃ¾e not wrong, Late hir nowe, to more and lasse, Be welcome to yowe Ã¾is Cristmasse. And Ã¾eos edoone, komeÃ¾e inne Ã¾e feorÃ¾e lady, cleped Dame Feyre and Wyse Attemperaunce. Ãis feorÃ¾e lady Ã¾at yee seon heer, Humble, debonayre and sadde of cheer, Ycalled is Attemperaunce; To sette al thing in gouuernaunce And for hir sustres to provyde, Vyces alle shal circumsyde, And setten hem in stabulnesse. With hir Cousin Soburnesse She shal frome vyces hem restreyne And in vertu holde hir reyne, And Ã¾er-inne gyf hem libertee, Eschuwing alle dishonestee; And hem enfourmen by prudence, For to haue pacyence, Lownesse and humylytee, And pruyde specyally to flee. Contynence frome gloutonye, Eschuwe deshoneste compaignye, Fleen Ã¾e dees and Ã¾e taverne, And in soburnesse hem gouverne; With hert al Ã¾at euer Ã¾ey can, In vertu loven euery man; Sey Ã¾e best ay of entent: Whoo Ã¾at seyÃ¾e weel, dooÃ¾e not repent. Detraccion and gloutouny, Voyde hem frome Ã¾y companye And al rancoure sette asuyde. Be not to hasty, but euer abyde, Specyally to doone vengeaunce; In aboode is no repentaunce. And in vertu whoo is Ã¾us sette, Ãanne beo Ã¾eos sustres weel ymette; And sooÃ¾ely, if it beo discerned, Who by Ã¾eos foure is Ã¾us gouuernedâ Ãus I mene: Ã¾at by Prudence He haue Ã¾e myrrour of Provydence. For to consider thinges alle, Naamely parylles, or Ã¾ey falleâ And who Ã¾at haue by gouuernaunce Of Rightwysnesse Ã¾e ballaunce, And strongly holde in his diffence Ãe swerd of hir Magnyfycence: Yee beon assured frome al meschaunce, Namely whanne Ã¾at Attemperaunce Hir sustre gouuerneÃ¾e al three. Frome Fortune yee may Ã¾ane go free, BooÃ¾e alwey in hert and thought. Whyle yee beo soo, ne dreed hir nought, But avoydeÃ¾e hir acqweyntaunce For hir double varyaunce, And fleoÃ¾e oute of hir companye And alle Ã¾at beon of hir allye. And yee foure susters, gladde of cheer, Shoule abyde here al Ã¾is yeer In Ã¾is housholde at libertee; And ioye and al prosparytee With yowe to housholde yee shoule bring. And yee all foure shal nowe sing With al youre hoole hert entiere Some nuwe songe aboute Ã¾e fuyre, Suche oon as you lykeÃ¾e best; Lat Fortune go pley hir wher hir list.
